text:
<@U0107JERE9L> in case this hasn't been shared before, see below open access training manuals that can be adapted/translated as appropriate.

A.	TRAINING MATERIALS (English plus additional languages)
1.	Clinical Care Severe Acute Respiratory Infection (<https://openwho.org/courses/severe-acute-respiratory-infection>) It is intended for clinicians who are working in intensive care units in low and middle-income countries and managing adult and pediatric patients with severe forms of acute respiratory infection.

2.	Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) for Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) (<https://openwho.org/courses/><https://openwho.org/courses/COVID-19-IPC-EN|COVID-19-IPC-EN>) This course provides information on what facilities should be doing to be prepared to respond to a case of an emerging respiratory virus such as COVID-19, how to identify a case once it occurs, and how to properly implement IPC measures to ensure there is no further transmission to health workers or to other patients and others in the healthcare facility. (Chinese, French, Italian, Japanese, Indonesian, Russian, Portuguese, Serbian, Spanish)

3.	Emerging respiratory viruses, including COVID-19: methods for detection, prevention, response and control (<https://openwho.org/courses/introduction-to-ncov>) This course provides a general introduction to COVID-19 and emerging respiratory viruses and is intended for public health professionals, incident managers and personnel working for the United Nations, international organizations and NGOs. (Arabic, Chinese, French, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Turkish)

4.	eProtect respiratory infections (<https://openwho.org/courses/eprotect-acute-respiratory-infections>) This course provides information on the basic knowledge and skills health workers need to respond to acute respiratory infection outbreaks, including what ARIs are, how they are transmitted, how to assess the risk of infection and to understand basic hygiene measures to protect themselves. (Chinese, French, Indonesian, Russian, Portuguese)

5.	How to put on, use, take off and dispose of a mask (<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lrvFrH_npQI&feature=youtu.be>)

6.	Public health interventions in pandemics and epidemics (<https://openwho.org/courses/public-health-interventions>) This introductory level online course provides information and tools for health workers to better manage disease outbreaks and health emergencies. Materials have been originally designed for WHO African region purposes and have therefore references to Africa more than other continents.

7.	Risk communication essentials (<https://openwho.org/courses/risk-communication>) Risk communication is a core public health intervention in any disease outbreak and health emergency. This course provides information on real-time exchange of information, advice and opinions between experts, officials and people who face a threat to their wellbeing, to enable informed decision-making and to adopt protective behaviors.


B.	HEALTH WORKER EXPOSURE & ASSESSMENT TOOLKIT (<https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/infection-prevention-and-control>) 

Health workers (HCWs) exposure risk assessment and management in the context of COVID-19 virus

This tool is to be used by health care facilities that have either cared for or admitted COVID-19 patients; it is to be completed for all health workers who have been exposed to a confirmed COVID-19 patient in a health care facility. It will help determine the risk of COVID-19 virus infection of all HCWs who have been exposed to a COVID-19 patient and then provides recommendations for appropriate management of these HCWs, according to their infection risk.

Find below the links to the template for collecting the data contained within the tool and a corresponding data dictionary to facilitate the collection of this data.
- Access the tool (<https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/331340/WHO-2019-nCov-HCW_risk_assessment-2020.1-eng.pdf>)

- Access to the data template (<https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/20200304-><https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/20200304-covid19-hcw-data-collection-form-final.xlsx?sfvrsn=ee0a7cff_2|covid19-hcw-data-collection-form-final.xlsx?sfvrsn=ee0a7cff_2>) 

- Access to the data dictionary (<https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/20200304-><https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/20200304-covid19-health-worker-data-dictionary-final.xlsx?sfvrsn=7484b927_2|covid19-health-worker-data-dictionary-final.xlsx?sfvrsn=7484b927_2>

root.text: Hi everyone, I'm an infectious disease epidemiologist. Let me know if there's anything in particular I can help support!

text: We (Ethio-American Doctors Group) are putting together a series of online webinars to share experiences in intensive care of the sick and infection control. We have held our first Zoom conf with medical schools/hospitals in Black Lion, Hawassa, Gonder, and we are waiting for connection with Jimma, Mekelle and Barhir Dar. We hope to reach 250 healthworkers. Also, we will pair critical care physicians here in US with colleagues in Ethiopia through WhatsApp for direct consultation. We have also started a gofundme effort and raised 1/3 of $100k (<https://slack-redir.net/link?url=https%3A%2F%2Ft.co%2FwqScbrEwxv%3Famp%3D1|gf.me/u/xsgra9>) goal to help health workers in Ethiopia. Finally, one of our members is a former Google Scientist who moved to Ethiopia with his family about a year or so ago. He teaches at Addis Ababa Univ. He will be great help on this effort. I have invited him to Slack: Solomon Gizaw, PhD <mailto:solomong@aau.edu.et|solomong@aau.edu.et>. I know this is information dump but wanted to share in one message. Mel <tel:2022715046|(202-271-5046>; <mailto:mnegussie@ethioamericandoctors.com|mnegussie@ethioamericandoctors.com>). I will post elsewhere as well. Thanks.

text:
Thank you very much for joining us here <@U010VLD0G2H>.. I am very happy to read what you and the group are doing.

Regarding reaching as many healthcare workers as possible,
• Could the ZOOM session be recorded and shared multiple times as needed by the folks there? Since internet connection is an issue, we can work together on getting the material downloaded and available offline.
• Do you have a training manual (PDFs) that we could share with the healthcare workers there again so they could use it offline. 
• There is an initiative to train volunteers, 4th and 5th year medical students as the number of patients increases. Do you have recommendations for training for those group of people?
Again thank you for what you are doing to help the most critical group in this situation.

elements.text: Thank you very much for joining us here

.. I am very happy to read what you and the group are doing.

Regarding reaching as many healthcare workers as possible,

Could the ZOOM session be recorded and shared multiple times as needed by the folks there? Since internet connection is an issue, we can work together on getting the material downloaded and available offline.
Do you have a training manual (PDFs) that we could share with the healthcare workers there again so they could use it offline.
There is an initiative to train volunteers, 4th and 5th year medical students as the number of patients increases. Do you have recommendations for training for those group of people?
Again thank you for what you are doing to help the most critical group in this situation.

text: Hi <!here>, I am country rep for an IT company that does a lot of IVR based remote training. We usually work with NGOs in helping them train their field staff. Our platform can send automated voice calls to any health care professional in Ethiopia and is easily scalable. Anyone here that can collaborate on this?

elements.text: Hi

, I am country rep for an IT company that does a lot of IVR based remote training. We usually work with NGOs in helping them train their field staff. Our platform can send automated voice calls to any health care professional in Ethiopia and is easily scalable. Anyone here that can collaborate on this?

text: I am not a health care expert but if you think of the frontline health workers throughout Ethiopia, there needs to be a way to share with them directives on how to handle Corona patients. I am sure FMOH is sharing information thru their channels, but using IVR you can have a way to keep a large majority of them informed of any directives.

elements.text: I am not a health care expert but if you think of the frontline health workers throughout Ethiopia, there needs to be a way to share with them directives on how to handle Corona patients. I am sure FMOH is sharing information thru their channels, but using IVR you can have a way to keep a large majority of them informed of any directives.

text: You can even push any new information directly to their phones, and track what percentage have listened to the full message.

elements.text: You can even push any new information directly to their phones, and track what percentage have listened to the full message.
